title: Do you think future composers can ever push the boundaries of music farther than composers such as Cage, Stockhausen, Boulez, etc. have? - Quora

response.answer_text: If by boundaries you mean the definition of what music can be, then I think no. John Cage demolished the borders between music and everything else almost single-handedly with his two milestones - 4′33″ and 0′00″. These works literally brought to life his “everything we do is music” manifesto. I might sound quite biased, but Karlheinz Stockhausen and Pierre Boulez, albeit very prominent composers, did not revolutionise music as much as John Cage did. There is another groundbreaker in music, who is kind of shrouded by Cage’s works, his name is La Monte Young. His Compositions 1960 (try to guess when they were composed) feature activities such as building a bonfire in front of the audience, drawing a straight line and releasing a butterfly. One of the compositions consists of the following instruction: “Most of them were very old grasshoppers.” La Monte managed to merge music and performance art in a more striking manner. Here is the performance of Composition 1960 #10  Nevertheless, what I have written above does not mean that there is nothing new to be invented in music. After all, Arnold Schoenberg, one of the pioneers of atonality, said: “There are still many good songs to be written in C Major” Music has got an infinite amount of possibilities, and will have forever
